Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 384, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 586, 724, 601]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 601, 590, 616]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 616, 606, 631]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 645, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 756, 676]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 676, 440, 691]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 87, 623, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 297, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
A hollow cylinder with a rough inner surface has radius \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\) is in contact with the inner surface of the cylinder. The particle and cylinder rotate together with angular speed \(6 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) about the vertical axis of the cylinder, so that the particle moves in a horizontal circle (see diagram). Given that \(P\) is about to slip downwards, find the coefficient of friction between \(P\) and the surface of the cylinder. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A small ball is projected from a point \(1.5 \mathrm{~m}\) above horizontal ground. At a point \(9 \mathrm{~m}\) above the ground the ball is travelling at \(45^{\circ}\) above the horizontal and its velocity is \(4 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) . Find the angle of projection of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 87, 640, 196]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 210, 920, 279]]<|/det|>
One end of a light inextensible string of length \(0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) is attached to a fixed point \(A\) which is above a smooth horizontal surface. A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.6 \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to the other end of the string. \(P\) moves in a circle on the surface with constant speed \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), with the string taut and making an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) with the horizontal (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 291, 156, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 291, 824, 308]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\nu = 0.5\), calculate the magnitude of the force that the surface exerts on \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 291, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 833, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest possible value of \(\nu\) for which \(P\) remains in contact with the surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(25 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) on horizontal ground. At time \(t\) s after projection the horizontal and vertically upwards displacements of \(P\) from \(O\) are \(x \mathrm{~m}\) and \(y \mathrm{~m}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 845, 153]]<|/det|>
Express \(x\) and \(y\) in terms of \(t\) and hence show that the equation of the trajectory of \(P\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 163, 561, 196]]<|/det|>
\[y = \frac{x}{\sqrt{3}} -\frac{4x^2}{375}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 189]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 860, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the horizontal distance between the two points at which \(P\) is \(5 \text{m}\) above the ground. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 37, 510, 56]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[811, 69, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 368, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
The new object is placed with its hemispherical part on a rough horizontal surface. The new object is held in equilibrium by a force of magnitude \(P \mathrm{N}\) acting along its axis of symmetry, which is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 153, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 433, 222, 451]]<|/det|>
Find \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 433, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) is released from rest at a point \(O\) on a rough plane inclined at \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal, and travels down a line of greatest slope. The coefficient of friction between \(P\) and the plane is 0.3. A force of magnitude \(0.6x \mathrm{N}\) acts on \(P\) in the direction \(PO\), where \(x \mathrm{m}\) is the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 151, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 149, 920, 193]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\nu \frac{\mathrm{d}\nu}{\mathrm{d}x} = 5\sqrt{3} - 1.5 - 3x\), where \(\nu \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) is the velocity of \(P\) at a displacement \(x \mathrm{m}\) from \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 178, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 191, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 511, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(x\) for which \(P\) reaches its maximum velocity, and calculate this maximum velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 533, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
